title: Big Ten teams are averaging only slightly fewer plays in 2023 than in 2022
text:
Load the tidyverse.


Code
library(tidyverse)


Create college football data frames for 2022 and 2023.


Code
logs22 <- read_csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs22.csv")
logs23 <- read_csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs23.csv")


Create a list of Big 10 teams.


Code
big10 <- c("Nebraska Cornhuskers", "Iowa Hawkeyes", "Minnesota Golden Gophers", "Illinois Fighting Illini", "Northwestern Wildcats", "Wisconsin Badgers", "Indiana Hoosiers", "Purdue Boilermakers", "Ohio State Buckeyes", "Michigan Wolverines", "Michigan State Spartans", "Penn State Nittany Lions", "Rutgers Scarlet Knights", "Maryland Terrapins")


Filter the data for 2022 using the Big 10 list.


Code
big22 <- logs22|> filter(TeamFull %in% big10)


Calculate the average number of offensive plays per Big 10 team in 2022.


Code
big22plays <- big22 |>
  group_by(TeamFull) |>
  summarise(
    avgPlays = mean(OffensivePlays)
  )


Make a bar chart of the 2022 Big Ten offensive play averages using ggplot. Add the weight of the average plays to the aesthetic and then reorder the teams by that weight. Add labels for the title and each axis.
Iowa clearly brings up the rear among teams in the Big 10 that averaged the most plays per game in 2022 at less than 60 plays per game. The Hawkeyes seem to value simply getting possessions and controlling the clock over getting off as many plays as possible. They are over 15 plays fewer than Purdue — the number one team of a top four of them, Northwestern, Indiana and Illinois. A lot of the teams in the Big 10 are bunched together around 70 plays or more per game, with the entirety of the top-half of the teams averaging over 69 plays per game.


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(
    data=big22plays, 
    aes(
      x=reorder(TeamFull, -avgPlays), weight = avgPlays)
  ) +
  labs(
    title="Iowa values possessions over plays", 
    x="School", 
    y="Average Plays Per Game"
  ) + 
  theme_minimal() + 
  coord_flip()





Filter the data for 2023 using the Big 10 list.


Code
big23 <- logs23|> filter(TeamFull %in% big10)


Calculate the average number of offensive plays per Big 10 team in 2023.


Code
big23plays <- big23 |>
  group_by(TeamFull) |>
  summarise(
    avgPlays = mean(OffensivePlays)
  )


Make a bar chart of the 2023 Big Ten offensive play averages using ggplot. Add the weight of the average plays to the aesthetic and then reorder the teams by that weight. Add labels for the title and each axis.
Penn State is way out in front among Big 10 teams in average plays per game up to this point in the 2023 season. Their 80.6 plays per game are over 7 more plays than second place, Purdue, and they’re averaging over 10 more plays per game this season than in 2022. Purdue and Wisconsin average over 70 plays per game as well to round out the top three, whilen Michigan and Iowa rank in the bottom two in the conference at less than 60 plays per game.


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(
    data=big23plays, 
    aes(
      x=reorder(TeamFull, avgPlays), weight = avgPlays)
  ) +
  labs(
    title="Penn State's fast-paced offense", 
    x="School", 
    y="Average Plays Per Game"
  ) + 
  theme_minimal() + 
  coord_flip()





Divide the sum of the entirety of the Big 10 teams’ 2022 plays by 14 to get the average number of plays for the conference. That gets an average of about 67.99.


Code
big22plays |>
  summarise(
    avgPlays = (sum(avgPlays))/14
  )


Divide the sum of the entirety of the Big 10 teams’ 2023 plays by 14 to get the average number of plays for the conference. That gets an average of about 66.16.


Code
big23plays |>
  summarise(
    avgPlays = (sum(avgPlays))/14
  )


The biggest takeaway to me is that Big 10 teams are running slightly fewer plays per game this season than in 2022, but not by much. Despite the NCAA aiming to shorten games — and in turn, possessions — by a noticeable margin through the new first down rule, Big 10 teams aren’t even averaging two less plays per game. There’s an influx of certain teams running more plays on average in 2023 — most notably Penn State and Wisconsin — and an influx of certain teams running less plays on average in 2023 — most notably Northwestern and Indiana — but at the end of the day, on average, there are only slightly less plays being run for the Big 10 teams.

title: Maryland does better passing than rushing on 3rd-and-6 in the Michael Locksley era
text:
Load the tidyverse.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(cfbfastR)


Load the play-by-play data.


Code
plays <- load_cfb_pbp(seasons = c(2019, 2020, 2021, 2022, 2023))


Find all plays where the down and distance is third-and-six. Save that to a new dataframe called “third_and_six”.


Code
third_and_six <- plays |> filter(down == 3, distance == 6)


Count the number of play types on third-and-six.


Code
third_and_six |> 
  group_by(play_type) |> 
  summarise(count = n())


What you get is 17 field goal attempts (1 blocked field goal + 13 successful field goals + 3 missed field goals), 142 fumbles (83 opponent fumble recoveries + 1 opponent fumble recovery touchdown + 55 own fumble recoveries + 3 fumble return touchdowns), 7,545 pass plays (182 interception returns + 24 interception return touchdowns + 2,859 pass incompletions + 3,484 pass receptions + 383 passing touchdowns + 613 sacks), 813 penalties, 3 punts, 2,459 runs (2,359 rushes + 100 rushing touchdowns), 2 safeties and 674 timeouts.
Around 21 percent of all third-and-six plays are runs, compared to around 65 percent of all third-and-six plays being passes.
Create a new dataframe of all of the rushes on third-and-six since 2019.


Code
rushplays <- third_and_six |> filter(play_type == 'Rush'| play_type == 'Rushing Touchdown')


Get the average yards gained on third-and-six rushes since 2019.


Code
rushplays |>
  summarise(
    mean_RYG = mean(yards_gained)
  )


Create a new dataframe of all of the passes on third-and-six since 2019.


Code
passplays <- third_and_six |> filter(play_type == 'Passing Touchdown'| play_type == 'Pass Reception' | play_type == 'Pass Incompletion' | play_type == 'Interception Return' | play_type == 'Interception Return Touchdown' | play_type == 'Sack')


Get the average yards gained on third-and-six passes since 2019.


Code
passplays |>
  summarise(
    mean_PYG = mean(yards_gained)
  )


On third-and-six, the average yards gained on runs was actually slightly higher (6.05) than on passes (5.85). In my opinion, the reason for that is the negative potential yards for a pass play — the most notable being interception returns — far outweights the negative potential yards for a rush.
Create new dataframes for rush plays on third-and-six for each season since 2019.


Code
rush2019 <- rushplays |> filter(year == '2019')




Code
rush2020 <- rushplays |> filter(year == '2020')




Code
rush2021 <- rushplays |> filter(year == '2021')




Code
rush2022 <- rushplays |> filter(year == '2022')




Code
rush2023 <- rushplays |> filter(year == '2023')


The most third-and-six rushes came in 2022, with 768 of them. Then followed was 2021 (507), 2019 (506), 2023 as of now (380) and 2020 (298).
Find out which team has the most third-and-six rushes in each year since 2019.


Code
rushplays |> 
  group_by(pos_team) |>
  summarise(count = n())|> 
  arrange(desc(count))


Navy has run the most times (49) on third-and-six since 2019.


Code
rush2019 |> 
  group_by(pos_team) |>
  summarise(count = n())|> 
  arrange(desc(count))


Georgia Southern ran the most times (13) on third-and-six in 2019.


Code
rush2020 |> 
  group_by(pos_team) |>
  summarise(count = n())|> 
  arrange(desc(count))


Navy ran the most times (12) on third-and-six in 2020.


Code
rush2021 |> 
  group_by(pos_team) |>
  summarise(count = n())|> 
  arrange(desc(count))


Army ran the most times (17) on third-and-six in 2021.


Code
rush2022 |> 
  group_by(pos_team) |>
  summarise(count = n())|> 
  arrange(desc(count))


Navy and Kennesaw State ran the most times (13) on third-and-six in 2022.


Code
rush2023 |> 
  group_by(pos_team) |>
  summarise(count = n())|> 
  arrange(desc(count))


Air Force, Prairie View, South Florida and West Virginia have run the most times (6) on third-and-six in 2023 so far.
Create a new dataframe showing only Maryland plays on third-and-six.


Code
md_third_and_six <- third_and_six |> filter(pos_team == "Maryland")


Count the number of Maryland’s play types on third-and-six.


Code
md_third_and_six |> 
  group_by(play_type) |> 
  summarise(count = n())


Among Maryland’s third-and-six plays since 2019, 2 of the them have resulted in fumble recoveries for the opposition, 33 are passes (1 interception + 11 incompletions + 13 receptions + 4 passing touchdowns + 4 sacks), 16 are runs (15 rushes + 1 rushing touchdown), 2 are penalties and 2 are timeouts.
Around 29 percent of Maryland’s third-and-six plays since 2019 are runs, compared to 60 pass plays.
Create a new dataframe of all of Maryland’s rushes on third-and-six since 2019.


Code
mdrushplays <- md_third_and_six |> filter(play_type == 'Rush'| play_type == 'Rushing Touchdown')


Get the average yards gained on Maryland’s third-and-six rushes since 2019.


Code
mdrushplays |>
  summarise(
    mean_RYG = mean(yards_gained)
  )


Maryland’s average yards gained on third-and-six runs since 2019 is 6.5.
Create a new dataframe of all of Maryland’s non-touchdown rushes on third-and-six since 2019.


Code
mdrushplays2 <- md_third_and_six |> filter(play_type == 'Rush')


Get the average yards gained on Maryland’s non-touchdown third-and-six rushes since 2019.


Code
mdrushplays2 |>
  summarise(
    mean_RYG = mean(yards_gained)
  )


Maryland’s average yards gained on non-touchdown third-and-six runs since 2019 is 5.9.
Create a new dataframe of all of Maryland’s simple pass completions on third-and-six since 2019.


Code
mdpassplays2 <- md_third_and_six |> filter(play_type == 'Pass Reception')


Get the average yards gained on Maryland’s simple pass completions on third-and-six since 2019.


Code
mdpassplays2 |>
  summarise(
    mean_RYG = mean(yards_gained)
  )


Maryland’s average yards gained on simple pass completions on third-and-six since 2019 is 11.
Create new dataframes for Maryland’s rush plays on third-and-six for each season since 2019.


Code
mdrush2019 <- mdrushplays |> filter(year == '2019')




Code
mdrush2020 <- mdrushplays |> filter(year == '2020')




Code
mdrush2021 <- mdrushplays |> filter(year == '2021')




Code
mdrush2022 <- mdrushplays |> filter(year == '2022')




Code
mdrush2023 <- mdrushplays |> filter(year == '2023')


Maryland’s most third-and-six rushes came in 2022, with 6 of them. Then followed was 2023 as of now (5), 2021 (4), 2019 (1) and 2020 (0).
Create a new dataframe of all of Maryland’s rushes and passes on third-and-six since 2019.


Code
mdrandpplays <- md_third_and_six |> filter(play_type == 'Rush'| play_type == 'Rushing Touchdown' | play_type == 'Passing Touchdown'| play_type == 'Pass Reception' | play_type == 'Pass Incompletion' | play_type == 'Interception Return' | play_type == 'Interception Return Touchdown' | play_type == 'Sack')




Code
mdrandpplays2 <- bind_rows(mdrushplays2, mdpassplays2)




Code
mdrandpplays3 <- mdrandpplays2 |> 
  group_by(play_type) |>
   summarise(
    avgyardsgained = mean(yards_gained) 
   )


Under head coach Michael Locksley, Maryland has historically passed the ball twice as often as it’s ran the ball on third-and-six. Also, taking only into account pass completions that don’t go for touchdowns and runs that don’t go for touchdowns — as in just trying to get the first down — the Terps on average will get five more yards through the air. That’s why it was so surprising when Maryland ran the ball on third-and-six against Illinois.


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(
    data=mdrandpplays3, 
    aes(x=reorder(play_type, -avgyardsgained), 
      weight=avgyardsgained)) +
  labs(
    title="Terps fare better through the air", 
    x="Type of Non-touchdown Play", 
    y="Average Yards Gained") + 
  theme_minimal()
